Influence || On Renaissance and Early Modern Philosophy
5.3 On Renaissance and Early Modern Philosophy

The late 16th and early 17th centuries saw efforts to form a
systematic synthesis of Christianity and Stoicism. The most important
figure in the Neo-Stoic movement was
 Justus Lipsius.
 The influence of the Hellenistic schools generally on early modern
philosophy is the theme of the essays collected in Miller and Inwood
2003. See also Osler 1991 and Strange and Zupko 2004.
